headline: What's behind China-Taiwan tensions? - BBC News
context: Many Taiwanese see their island as separate nation

annotations.paragraph: China has launched major military drills around Taiwan for the second time this year, simulating a full-scale attack on the island - just days after the Taiwanese President William Lai delivered his first National Day speech.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides new information about recent military drills by China and their timing in relation to Taiwan's political events.

annotations.paragraph: They come months after drills held, days after Lai was sworn in.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the timing of the drills in relation to political events in Taiwan.

annotations.paragraph: The exercises reinforce what is at the heart of the issue: China's claim over self-governed Taiwan.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the significance of the military exercises in the context of China's claim over Taiwan.

annotations.paragraph: Beijing sees the island as a breakaway province that will, eventually, be part of the country, and has not ruled out the use of force to achieve this.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential context about China's perspective on Taiwan.

annotations.paragraph: But many Taiwanese consider themselves to be part of a separate nation - although most are in favour of maintaining the status quo where Taiwan neither declares independence from China nor unites with it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers important context on the Taiwanese perspective and the current political stance.

annotations.paragraph: Taiwan's first known settlers were Austronesian tribal people, believed to have come from modern day southern China.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context about Taiwan's early settlers relevant to understanding its history.

annotations.paragraph: Chinese records appear to first mention the island in AD239, when an emperor dispatched an expeditionary force to it - a fact Beijing uses to back its territorial claim.
annotations.reason: Offers historical context that supports China's territorial claims, relevant to the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: After a relatively brief spell as a Dutch colony, Taiwan was administered by China's Qing dynasty, before it was ceded to Tokyo after Japan won the First Sino-Japanese War.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on Taiwan's governance, relevant to its complex history.

annotations.paragraph: After World War Two, Japan surrendered and relinquished control of territory it had taken from China. Afterwards, Taiwan was officially considered occupied by the Republic of China (ROC), which began ruling with the consent of its allies, the US and UK.
annotations.reason: Explains the post-WWII status of Taiwan, relevant to its political status.

annotations.paragraph: But in the next few years a civil war broke out in China, and then-leader Chiang Kai-shek's troops were defeated by Mao Zedong's Communist army.
annotations.reason: Describes the civil war in China, relevant to the political split affecting Taiwan.

annotations.paragraph: Chiang, the remnants of his Kuomintang (KMT) government and their supporters - about 1.5m people -  fled to Taiwan in 1949.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on the origins of Taiwan's current political status.

annotations.paragraph: Chiang established a dictatorship that ruled Taiwan until the 1980s. Following his death, Taiwan began a transition to democracy and held its first elections in 1996.
annotations.reason: Details the political evolution of Taiwan, relevant to understanding current tensions.

annotations.paragraph: There is disagreement about the status of Taiwan.
annotations.reason: Introduces the central issue of Taiwan's contested status.

annotations.paragraph: It has its own constitution, democratically-elected leaders, and about 300,000 active troops in its armed forces.
annotations.reason: Provides key facts about Taiwan's independent governance and military.

annotations.paragraph: Chiang's ROC government-in-exile at first claimed to represent the whole of China, which it intended to re-occupy. It held China's seat on the United Nations Security Council and was recognised by many Western nations as the only Chinese government.
annotations.reason: Explains the historical international recognition of Taiwan's government, relevant to its current status.

annotations.paragraph: Image source, Central Press
annotations.reason: This is an image caption and does not contribute to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Chiang Kai-shek, once the leader in China, fled with his supporters to Taiwan
annotations.reason: This provides historical context about the origins of Taiwan's separate government.

annotations.paragraph: But by the 1970s some countries began to argue that the Taipei government could no longer be considered a genuine representative of the people living in mainland China.
annotations.reason: This explains the shift in international recognition away from Taiwan.

annotations.paragraph: In 1971, the UN switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing.  Once China began opening up its economy in 1978, the US recognised opportunities for trade and the need to develop relations. It formally established diplomatic ties with Beijing in 1979.
annotations.reason: This provides key historical events that affected Taiwan's international status.

annotations.paragraph: Since then the number of countries that recognise the ROC government has fallen drastically with only 12 countries recognising the island today. China exerts considerable diplomatic pressure on other countries not to recognise Taiwan.
annotations.reason: This details the current diplomatic situation and China's influence.

annotations.paragraph: Relations started improving in the 1980s as Taiwan relaxed rules on visits to and investment in China. In 1991, the ROC proclaimed that the war with the People's Republic of China was over.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on the improvement of relations and a significant political declaration.

annotations.paragraph: China proposed the so-called "one country, two systems" option, which it said would allow Taiwan significant autonomy if it agreed to come under Beijing's control.
annotations.reason: Introduces a key proposal from China that is central to the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: This system underpinned Hong Kong's return to China in 1997 and the manner in which it was governed until recently, when Beijing has sought to increase its influence.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the 'one country, two systems' model by relating it to Hong Kong.

annotations.paragraph: Taiwan rejected the offer, leading Beijing to insist the Taiwan's ROC government was illegitimate - but unofficial representatives from China and Taiwan still held limited talks.
annotations.reason: Describes Taiwan's response and the resulting diplomatic situation.

annotations.paragraph: Then in 2000, Taiwan elected Chen Shui-bian as president, much to Beijing's alarm.
annotations.reason: Highlights a significant political event that affected China-Taiwan relations.

annotations.paragraph: Chen and his party, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), had openly backed Taiwan "independence".
annotations.reason: Provides context on political stance relevant to Taiwan-China tensions.

annotations.paragraph: A year after Chen was re-elected in 2004, China passed a so-called anti-secession law, declaring China's right to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan if it tried to "secede" from China.
annotations.reason: Details a significant legislative action by China impacting Taiwan relations.

annotations.paragraph: Chen was later succeeded by the KMT, which favours closer relations with the PRC.
annotations.reason: Explains a shift in Taiwan's political leadership affecting cross-strait relations.

annotations.paragraph: In 2016, Tsai Ing-wen, from the DPP, was elected to the presidency. Under her, cross-strait relations have soured. China also cut off official communications with Taiwan after Ms Tsai took over, saying it was because of her refusal to endorse the concept of a single Chinese nation.
annotations.reason: Describes recent developments in Taiwan-China relations under Tsai's leadership.

annotations.paragraph: Tsai has never said she will formally declare Taiwan's independence, insisting that it is already independent.
annotations.reason: Clarifies Tsai's stance on Taiwan's independence, relevant to the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: Image source, Reuters
annotations.reason: This is an image caption and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Under Ms Tsai, cross-Straits relations soured again
annotations.reason: This provides context on the deterioration of relations under Tsai's leadership.

annotations.paragraph: But Tai's term also coincided with that of Xi Jinping, under whom Chinese claims have grown more aggressive. He has reiterated the message that China will "surely be reunified" with Taiwan, and has set 2049 as a target date for "achieving the Chinese dream".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides important context on Xi Jinping's stance and its impact on China-Taiwan relations.

annotations.paragraph: In January 2024, Taiwan elected Tsai's vice-president, William Lai, as president - a man China has branded a "separatist".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the new Taiwanese president and China's view of him.

annotations.paragraph: China's drills - dubbed Joint Sword 2024A - came in his first week in office - which Beijing said were a "strong punishment" for "separatist acts". It also singled out Lai as the "worst of all" DPP presidents so far.
annotations.reason: This paragraph details China's military response to the new Taiwanese president, which is directly relevant to the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: The second round of drills - titled Joint Sword 2024B - came days after Lai pledged to uphold Taiwan's self-governing status during a national day speech on 10 October.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about military drills and political statements relevant to Taiwan's self-governance.

annotations.paragraph: The US maintains official ties with Beijing, and recognises it as the only Chinese government under its "One China policy" - but it also remains Taiwan's most significant international supporter.
annotations.reason: Explains the US's diplomatic stance and its significance to Taiwan, relevant to the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: Washington is bound by law to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons and US President Joe Biden has said that the US would defend Taiwan militarily - breaking with a stance known as strategic ambiguity.
annotations.reason: Details US legal obligations and policy shifts regarding Taiwan, relevant to the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: The island has long been one of the most contentious issue in US-China relations, with Beijing condemning any perceived support from Washington for Taipei. In 2022, after a visit to Taiwan by US Speaker Nancy Pelosi, China responded with an unprecedented show of force, carrying out military exercises around Taiwan in retaliation.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context and specific incidents illustrating the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: Under President Xi, China has ramped up this "grey zone warfare" - sending record numbers of Chinese fighter jets near Taiwan and holding military drills in response to political exchanges between the US and Taiwan. In 2022, China's warplane incursions into Taiwan's Air Defence Identification Zone (ADIZ) nearly doubled.
annotations.reason: Describes China's military actions and their escalation, directly relevant to the tensions.

annotations.paragraph: The results of the elections will shape the course of US-China relations - and no matter who walks away the winner, will have an indelible impact on the delicate relationship between the US, China and Taiwan.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context on how election outcomes could influence US-China-Taiwan relations, which is relevant to the topic of tensions.
